title: Nashia inaguensis
text:
Nashia inaguensis is an <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a>, commonly referred to as Moujean tea, Bahamas berry, or pineapple verbena. It is native to the east <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> islands, in particular the island of <a href="Inagua">Inagua</a> in the <a href="Bahamas">Bahamas</a>, after which the species is named. In its native environment, the plant crawls along sunny, rocky outcroppings, semi-protected from steady high winds.
It is a loose, spreading shrub with many branches up to 2 m high, with mature trunks of 5–10 cm diameter. The <a href="Leaf">leaves</a> are aromatic, simple, opposite (or fascicled), elliptic to obovate or spatulate, 5–10 mm long, with revolute margins. The <a href="flower">flower</a>heads are axillary, sessile, few-flowered, with a strigose calyx; the corolla is whitish, about 2 mm long, four-lobed, and with four stamens. The fragrant foliage and tiny white flowers are highly attractive to pollinators, in particular the <a href="Eumaeus%20atala">Atala butterfly</a>.
Cultivation and uses.
It is often used as a bonsai plant due to its miniaturized features. The flowers form in clusters and are followed by reddish orange berries. It prefers full sun, warmth (a minimum temperature of 5 °C) and must be kept under high humidity. Even a brief spell of dryness can kill the plant. It can be propagated from cuttings, preferably in the spring and early summer during warm nights. A <a href="decoction">decoction</a> of the fragrant leaves, variously described as having the scent and flavor of citrus, vanilla, or pineapple, is used as an herbal tea.
